hints_html:
The integrand is a fraction of polynomials. What integration technique is ideal for this situation?

Try partial fractions!
hints_latex:
The integrand is a fraction of polynomials. What integration technique
is ideal for this situation?
hints_raw:
The integrand is a fraction of polynomials. What integration technique is ideal for this situation?
Try partial fractions!
question: 1 (c)
sols_html:
This is a rational function, so we try partial fractions. The integrand’s denominator can be factored, then we apply partial fraction decomposition giving

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{dx}{x+x^2} &= \frac{1}{x(1+x)} \\ &= \frac{A}{x} + \frac{B}{1+x}\end{aligned}\]

Cross multiplying,

\[\begin{aligned} 1 &= A(1+x) + Bx\end{aligned}\]

We can solve this several ways.

(1) Setting \(\displaystyle x = 0\) we get \(\displaystyle 1 = A\), and setting \(\displaystyle x = -1\) we get \(\displaystyle 1 = -B\), so \(\displaystyle B = -1\).

(2) Comparing coefficients of the constant term, we get \(\displaystyle 1 = A\), and then comparing coefficients of the \(\displaystyle x\) term, we get \(\displaystyle 0 = A+B = 1+B\), so \(\displaystyle B = -1\).

(3) We get \(\displaystyle A = 1\) and \(\displaystyle B = -1\) by inspection.

Now we solve the integral:

\[\begin{aligned} \int_1^2 \frac{dx}{x+x^2} &= \int_1^2 \frac{dx}{x(1+x)} \\ &= \int_1^2 \left( \frac1{x} + \frac{-1}{1+x}\right)\,dx \\ &= \left( \ln|x| - \ln|1+x|\right)\big|_1^2 \\ &= (\ln 2 - \ln 3) - (\ln 1 - \ln 2) \\ &= 2\ln 2 - \ln 3\end{aligned}\]

The answer \(\ln \frac43\) is equivalent.
sols_latex:
This is a rational function, so we try partial fractions. The
integrand's denominator can be factored, then we apply partial fraction
decomposition giving

\begin{align*}
\frac{dx}{x+x^2} &= \frac{1}{x(1+x)} \\
&= \frac{A}{x} + \frac{B}{1+x}
\end{align*}

Cross multiplying,

\begin{align*}
1 &= A(1+x) + Bx
\end{align*}

We can solve this several ways.

(1) Setting $\displaystyle x = 0$ we get $\displaystyle 1 = A$, and
setting $\displaystyle x = -1$ we get $\displaystyle 1 = -B$, so
$\displaystyle B = -1$.

(2) Comparing coefficients of the constant term, we get
$\displaystyle 1 = A$, and then comparing coefficients of the
$\displaystyle x$ term, we get $\displaystyle 0 = A+B = 1+B$, so
$\displaystyle B = -1$.

(3) We get $\displaystyle A = 1$ and $\displaystyle B = -1$ by
inspection.

Now we solve the integral:

\begin{align*}
\int_1^2 \frac{dx}{x+x^2} &= \int_1^2 \frac{dx}{x(1+x)} \\
&= \int_1^2 \left( \frac1{x} + \frac{-1}{1+x}\right)\,dx \\
&= \left( \ln|x| - \ln|1+x|\right)\big|_1^2 \\
&= (\ln 2 - \ln 3) - (\ln 1 - \ln 2) \\
&= 2\ln 2 - \ln 3
\end{align*}

The answer $\ln \frac43$ is equivalent.
sols_raw:
This is a rational function, so we try partial fractions. The integrand's denominator can be factored, then we apply partial fraction decomposition giving

:<math>
\displaystyle
\begin{align}
\frac{dx}{x+x^2} &= \frac{1}{x(1+x)} \\
& = \frac{A}{x} + \frac{B}{1+x}
\end{align}
</math>

Cross multiplying,

:<math>
\displaystyle
\begin{align}
1 &= A(1+x) + Bx
\end{align}
</math>

We can solve this several ways. 

(1) Setting <math> \displaystyle x = 0</math> we get <math> \displaystyle 1 = A</math>, and setting <math> \displaystyle x = -1</math> we get <math> \displaystyle 1 = -B</math>, so <math> \displaystyle B = -1</math>.

(2) Comparing coefficients of the constant term, we get <math> \displaystyle 1 = A</math>, and then comparing coefficients of the <math>\displaystyle x </math> term, we get <math> \displaystyle 0 = A+B = 1+B</math>, so <math> \displaystyle B = -1</math>.

(3) We get <math> \displaystyle A = 1</math> and <math> \displaystyle B = -1</math> by inspection.

Now we solve the integral:

:<math>
\displaystyle
\begin{align}
\int_1^2 \frac{dx}{x+x^2} &= \int_1^2 \frac{dx}{x(1+x)} \\
&= \int_1^2 \left( \frac1{x} + \frac{-1}{1+x}\right)\,dx \\
&= \left( \ln|x| - \ln|1+x|\right)\big|_1^2 \\
&= (\ln 2 - \ln 3) - (\ln 1 - \ln 2) \\
&= 2\ln 2 - \ln 3
\end{align}
</math>

The answer  <math>\ln \frac43 </math> is equivalent.
statement_html:
Short-Answer Questions. Question 1-3 are short-answer questions. Put your answer in the box provided. Simplify your answer as much as possible. Full Marks will be awarded for a correct answer placed in the box. Show your work, for part marks.

Evaluate

\[\begin{aligned} \int_1^2 \frac{dx}{x+x^2}\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
